I was staying here on a business trip. The front desk service was pretty good, not overly enthusiastic, but friendly enough. I checked in at noon, but the room wasn't going to be ready until 3 pm. I had to do a booth setup anyways. None of the lines were really moving all that quickly. If it were a personal trip, I would've self checked in at a kiosk, but didn't have the credit card used to book which I think was a requirement.

They also received a package from my work sent to me and delivered it to the palace ballroom for me. There was even a voicemail to my room before I checked in about it.

I came back at 3 pm, got a couple of keycards. Short line. They drew a map for me to find the right Palace elevators which are in the back by the pool area. It's not the most convenient spot if you want to hit the strip, but again, I wasn't paying for the room. If you have have a chance for a lot of pool time though, it doesn't get much better. No 13th floor officially.

The room had a king sized bed, TV, mini bar, couch, chairs. The bathroom had a stand up shower, a tub with jacuzzi jets, dual sinks and a room for the toilet. The turn down service was good. No complaints.

CP is located pretty well. Right near the Bellagio bridge and you can head across the strip to Bally's side. The heat that weekend was horrible so being well located to so many decent spots was great. The taxi and uber pickup at night was pretty crowded. For airport shuttles, they pick up at a different exit through the casino instead of the lobby, and on the other side of the fountain away from the taxis and limos pickup. They start at 6:30 am. Ask the reception. Have cash if you didn't buy a return ticket.

It's apparent that Ceasar's Palace has developed an elitist mentality that has degraded their sense of customer service. The first night I checked in, I was placed into a smoking room because (allegedly) they had no non-smoking rooms. The next day, I was DOWNGRADED and moved clear across the enormous  complex to one of the few remaining non-smoking rooms. I tried to bring up the matter with the front desk, but all I got was a shrug and an "oh well, that's all we have for you." 
During my stay I had to call the front desk several times for lights, television, and fridge issues. I even had to call once because a man had been passed out in the hallway a few doors down from me... Not necessarily their fault, but I couldn't believe security didn't take care of him before my call, especially considering it could have been a medical emergency!
Throughout my stay, I was met by ever more uncaring staff, including the annoying "room service" knocks, despite the fact that I'd placed my "Do Not Disturb" notice on the door the night prior.
Needless to say, I will NEVER stay or play at CP again! I hope others heed this warning and stop giving CP business. Maybe then, the resort will realize the importance of treating their customers fairly. 
(The only reason I rated 2 stars instead of 1 is because the resort is beautiful, including the rooms, and most especially the pool.)

Second time I've stayed at Caesar's Palace and absolutely enjoy the atmosphere of this hotel. The architecture is beautifully done, and the pools are amazing :3 

We stayed at the standard room and it already felt so much nicer than other standard rooms on the strip. With central air conditioning, a t.v. integrated into the bathroom mirror, and dual shower heads (one of them a rainfall shower head), I was in heaven. 

Some things I didn't like - 1. Everything costs money, including in-room coffee! 2. The handle to the bathroom door in our room was badly misplaced and I ended up getting a deep cut on my finger because of it. 3. The last view from our room was not the best, to say the least.

$7 toast and $16 12" cheese pizza, $12 bowl of apple jacks... This place has crashed and burned in the past few years. Old rooms, poor service. I used to love this place... I'll never stay here again. HORRIBLE.

On our arrival the bellman was OUTSTANDING, he told us what and where everything was on our way to our room. Our room in the Palace Tower was a mini suite, when we booked we got offered a buy up for a suite if available on check in, it was and what a steal for an extra $17 a night.
 So many great restaurants to choose from you could stay here and never go any where else but there are a couple of down sides, Starbucks was always understaffed no matter when we got there, peak breakfast rush one person making drinks and two ringing in orders with a line down the hallway. Central is a great breakfast option, food is good but it depends on your server, your wait could be a while. Payard is over priced poorly made classic french dishes, a total let down.
 We only stayed in house for dinner a couple of nights, Nobu is a DON'T miss, Gordon Ramsay Pub & Grill was good food for a good price and the food court give alots of options but be warned it closes at 11pm. This  is the down side to Caesars, there is very little late night choices for food.
 We only encounter one member of staff on the Casino floor that truly stood out, Steve on the Craps table in the back near Gordon Ramsay's.
  Over all this is a nice property but it would be so much better is the staff and the total experience lived up to the Caesar's name. We liked out stay and will visit the property again just not sure if we would stay here again.

Caesar's Palace, you are the WORST hotel\/casino that I've stayed at during my trips to Vegas.

Short story:
- Messed up our comps when confirmed they were available
- Dirty band aid in our hotel bathroom
- Broken faucets
- No video roulette
- Housemaid didn't replenish our bathroom toiletries after the first night

Long story:
My boyfriend, a total rewards member was graciously comped 5 free nights plus food comps at any of the Caesar's properties. And without a doubt, Caesar's would be first on our list. When I booked the hotel, I was confirmed that the nights were free and the food comps were available. After a sickening flight, we were told that we did not make reservations under the same code and was not offered other comps as substitution. Disappointed, we went upstairs to check out our hotel room. After a quick tour, I stepped into the bathroom and there it lay. A DIRTY BAND AID. Just there. Laying. On the ground. I was appalled that this institution supposedly reputable and gorgeous had such a disgusting slip up. Furthermore, the faucets were broken. HOW DO YOU HAVE BROKEN FAUCETS THAT YOU DON'T BOTHER TO FIX? Then the cleaning lady didn't even bother to replenish our bathroom toiletries. The whole time at Caesar's was a disappointment. In all, Caesar's is nice on the outside and the casino floor. I wouldn't bother to come back to Caesar's to stay the night though.

Stayed at Caesar's Palace on the first and last night of my stay this past trip.  The first night I was given a fantastic room upgrade, with my own spacious king-size bed, a view of the pool and a luxurious tub with jets in the Octavius Tower.  That was a 5 star experience.  The final night I stayed in the Forum Tower, which was less enjoyable.  I could hear music and bass from the club throughout the evening.  Not a huge issue for me as that I find pretty enjoyable, but worth noting if you are looking for quiet room.  Also, in the hallway there I encountered a couple drunk sobbing girls during my midnight snack run, nothing too major but I was just hoping for a quick, peaceful trip downstairs.  The pools are expansive and very nice.  Bring some chips down to them with you, as you can play blackjack while you sit in the pool and drink and enjoy the water.

Plenty of restaurants lie within Caesar's Palace and even more sit in the Forum Shops, attached to Caesar's.  My big complaint would be the long lines at check-in and the location of some of the rooms within the hotel.  Also a plus (although I didn't experience it) is that Caesar's has the supposed best buffet in Vegas.

I'm a big fan of Cesar's. The first time I went the people at the front desk treat you like royalty. "Mr. England! We're so happy to see you again!" even though I had never been there. I would usually think this is cheesy but they ended up upgrading me to a suite! 

This was the greatest hotel room I've ever stayed in. It was about 3000 square feet of pure luxury! Next time I went though, got stuck in the basic room. Can't expect that kind of hook up every time but they have definitely earned my business!
Love this place! Rooms are awesome !! It is very large space in the casino area so a lot of walking.Celine show best in Vegas.
2nd rate. The AC can't keep up even in March. They need better air filters as well.long lines to cash out. Staff was helpful and friendly.

If what you want is luxury and a price tag to match, you will probably like Caesars. I had to stay there for a conference and hated it. (But let me say up front: I hate Las Vegas, so it would have been hard to please me, and I basically never stay in luxury hotels because I resent their business model of squeezing cash out of their guests at every turn.)

Pros: it's a luxury hotel, so they get all the obvious things right--clean, comfortable rooms, jacuzzi in the room, good bell service, good doorman for hailing a cab.

Cons: like many luxury hotels, they nickel and dime you for things you would get for free at Best Western; to use the gym and internet you have to pay a $29\/day resort fee, but if you use the internet _in_ the gym, there's an additional $10 roaming fee; there's a Keurig coffee maker in the room, but the coffee, cream, and sugar are part of the mini-bar and will cost you $13; it's basically impossible to move around the hotel without walking through the casino (by design,of course); smoking is allowed in the casino, so walking from my room to the gym meant walking through a cloud of smoke; the food in the food court is overpriced (for example, a burger, fries, and fountain soda is about $18). I felt like a rat trapped in a very expensive maze.

And of course the worst downside is that it's in Las Vegas.

If you're still reading, here's one tip: there's a small shop called the Emperor's Essentials, which sells snacks, liquor, cigarettes and knickknacks. The prices there are completely reasonable--pretty much what you'd pay at any convenience store.

Definitely beats the last hotels I stayed at, palazzo and PH, but not as great as those higher end hotels (cosmo, wynn). We got the rewards membership and got discounted rooms, pretty decent room. Very clean and simple. The great thing about this hotel is that it is HUGE and there's SO MUCH to do. The forum shops are great. Lots of stuff to do in Caesars! Check in isnt till later in the day but we were able to check in early before noon. I recommend people to  try to checkin early if they want and most likely you'll be able to get your room early, since rooms are usually available. 

If I had to save money I'll def stay at this hotel. Its inbetween 2 great nightclubs, XS and Marquee, right in the middle of the strip. So many restaurants and shops and things to do in Caesar, you really can't go wrong at this classic hotel.

Thank Caesar's ghost we had reward club passes for a free two night stay because I would've been LIVID if we had paid their exorbitant $729 per room per night for a room! Sure, our room looked nice, but I wasn't pleased to see how filthy everything was and didn't like the feeling I might get charged to touch something. I didn't expect to see dirty doors, walls, ripped fabrics, damaged walls and torn lampshades, and the finding the previous occupants socks under the bed was a surprise, too. Add these things to the ridiculously overpriced in-room snacks and minibar items (seriously, they provide a Kuerig to use, but can't spare a couple of complimentary K-cups and some sugar?!?) found the place way too big to navigate and don't even get me started on how rude the registration staff was (his name is Amoud, I'd avoid him, he seems cranky) I was perturbed to learn at check in they require a $200 deposit for our stay, information that was not relayed during my call to make reservations. Then we have the "resort fee" of $28 per night, which did include one free day of wifi for one device (to use other devices would be yet another charge at $14.99 per device per day) and I found to be super slow. Overall, 2 stars for the very grand appearance of the place, the deep spa tub & location, but other than that, I won't be back. Even with the complimentary stay,  there is no such thing as "free.

Walking around here is a bit annoying; the place is massive. It is a long walk through the casino from self parking to the Roman towers for example - all indoors though. Parking is free. The property was insanely busy with people walking through it to get to other parts of the strip, gamble, go to one of the bars or restaurants, or just look around. It all was very nice and clean though which for the level of foot traffic was impressive. 

The pools are for hotel guests only (there is an attendant to check key cards). There are many pools to choose from though they all resemble a Greek style design. The lounge chairs are rather comfortable and do not need to be reserved. The thicker cushioned lounges ($300) and of course the cabanas need to be reserved ahead of time. The Garden of the Gods pool closes at 6p Saturday and the others an hour later which I just can't understand. All in all a very enjoyable complex. 

Room 780 in Romans tower was traditional, but massive! There was a couch and two chairs making up a seating area - albeit around an outdated disappointing in cabinet television. The bathroom was large as well with a toilet and bidet separated into another room. The main door to 780 was behind another door off the hallway. The keycard was required for both doors. Next to the internal door was a door to another room - I am guessing for adjoining purposes.

The shops were really cool. The ceiling looks like sky and all the buildings have their own roofs which make for a good "skyline." The center area kind of reminded me of St Peters Square with all the figures around it.

First of all the check-in lines were long and the self check-in kiosks wouldn't recognize my credit card or other ID.  The person behind the desk was polite and helpful. The cleaning staff was very good and professional during my four night stay this past August of 2017.  Everything thereafter went downhill.  All the fees they have for every little thing is quite disturbing.  This isn't the Vegas I remember. It's been approximately seven years since my last visit and my final one ever.  Corporate greed once again corporate greed.  Just like the gentlemen at the check-in counter told me Vegas is geared for corporate events and no longer a family destination. How right he is.  The facilities are well maintained and clean, but that's where it stops.  To park your car is $12 a day.  Nevada residents park for free.  The resort fee is approximately $40 a night per room and they will not waive it don't ask you're wasting your time.  For four nights I paid an additional $210 approximately on top of my hotel room.  Mr. CEO desert sand is free go eat some.  Corporate greed is pushing working families away from Vegas dot be fooled. Furthermore, the Buffett is quite expensive, however, it's worth the price. The only draw back is you enter your phone number into a kiosk tells you that you'll be texted as to when to come back to be seated or so I thought. After waiting over an hour I was texted, but I realized once I got there I had to wait an additional thirty plus minutes after being texted in line.   Great food, but my company felt like everyone was treated like crap. Total wait time for dinner almost two hours.  Overall, this place nor the rest of Vegas will ever get my business again. I clearly see that Vegas is no longer family friendly.

Snafus at check in, indifferent staff, way too many "bros" living out their Jersey Shore or Hangover fantasies. Mediocre room with no coffeemaker, overcrowded pool, overpriced restaurants. Ended up spending most of my time at Bill's where the slots were looser and the crowd wasn't so full of themselves!

I didn't stay here but walked through plenty of times. Great shops, great restaurants...clean casino. VERY PRICY, just be warned. and huge. HUGE. definitely one of the biggest if not the biggest hotel on the strip. walked easily 5 miles a day alone in Caesar's. GORGEOUS, completely beautiful and shows very few signs of age or wear and tear. Will say that the price is off-putting so be prepared to pay nearly double for everything in this hotel.
great service friendly staff not like the jackasses in wynn

When checking into the hotel we were treated horribly. We were told our room reservation was not able to be met due to specific departments refusing to give us a roll away bed. We have 3 adults here for a work conference. Guess I will get to know my coworkers really well. We were informed our room was upgraded to a smaller yet newer room- the situation is getting worse. Then we were told to be grateful for the $75 food credit for the 3 days we will be here. ( Musse is who checked us in) Nothing was offered to rectify the situation but to pay them an outrageous fee for a second room. Upon getting to this "upgraded room" it is very small and has the view of cars and the AC units. They could have just told us to go somewhere else if they didn't want our business. We spoke with the "manager" ( Gillian Rigglenan) who talked down to us as if we were scum. I do not recommend this hotel at all. Save your money and time!

I am on my fourth telephone call to Caesars as I write this review.  I have been trying to get rates for the new hotel Nobu.  The first time I called, I gave the representative all of the required information, she said she was transferring me to VIP so that I would get the best rate.  I listened to a recording thanking me for holding for over 15 minutes.  I hung up and called back, same scenario.  I hung up and called back, this third time no one answered.  I hung up and called back, this time I decided to remain on hold because by now I want to speak with a Manager - I'm pissed!  The Manager only made excuse after excuse as to why customer service was so poor.  Prices at Nobu are not cheap.  I expect better customer service - first impressions!  I go to Las Vegas often so I try to experience all of the hotels that I can afford, good planning allows me to stay at some of the nicer ones.  I can cross Caesars off my list because I will not be staying there.  I am truly annoyed with the service, or lack thereof!

Disgusting conditions, run down rooms, and terrible service, all wrapped in one experience. I only wish I could give zero stars. 

Number one complaint, upon noticing a large red stain on the comforter, that could no way have been left by myself, I requested a new comforter. Woke up today, saw that instead, they had just tucked the stained corner in under a bottom corner of the bed. 

Between the 1.5 hour late check-in that was handled with poor customer service, the COLD showers, and the power going out to our tower's elevators causing us to be lead around through the back hallways of the hotel, I was not impressed. Oh, and the gentleman who was escorting my friend and I, ABANDONED US in the elevator when we expressed our displeasure at the situation. 

Also, our room appeared that it hadn't been refurbished in 30+ years. High dollar for Motel 8 quality.

One of the classic hotels on the strip, worth visiting to gawk and indulge at the Bacchanal Buffet.

It's looking a bit dated, like something out of Scarface, but really, who doesn't secretly want a mansion like that? Worth a trip to check it out.

If I could give Caesars 10 stars, I would! 

My fiancé and I were so blown away with the customer service that we received last year that we decided to book our anniversary trip here again. We stayed in the exact same type of suite in the Octavius tower and the suite was just as gorgeous as we remembered. From the very first moment we arrived to our eventual check-out, we felt great knowing that we had made our annual trip back here. We decided early on to keep our activities pretty centralized to Caesars as it was SO hot this year. 

We began our trip with an anniversary dinner at Nobu. The food completely blew us away and was incredibly impressive. I was delighted by every single dish we had! 

This year we were also able to take advantage of the absolutely exquisite pools outside and that was a great treat! I especially enjoyed drinking mimosas by the pool since it was so hot (115+!). 

We also enjoyed the Bacchanal Buffet on our last full day here, and that did not disappoint. 

I wanted to give a special shout out to Leah for her superb coordination throughout our stay. We absolutely loved our experience staying here and have recommended your hotel to all of our family and friends.

This year for Christmas my S.O. and I decided to give each other a mini trip to Las Vegas to see the Reba with Brooks & Dunn concert at Caesars. Since the concert was to be held at Caesars that's where we wanted to make our overnight arrangements. I had called the resort months in advance to assure a nice room\/suite\/whatever with a view of the strip, being able to watch the Fountains at Bellagio from the balcony or window. I received confirmation shortly after.  "Thank you for choosing The Laurel Collection by Caesars Palace." (Only upon checking out did I discover that they charged you for calling them to make a reservation...$16.80. What a rip off!)  Great, everything's all set. I am slightly handicapped so more time than the average would be spent sitting, looking at the view from the room's balcony, windows, etc. Later I get this email from them;
"Skip the Line with Self Check-In
Look for an email the morning of your arrival inviting you to check in online. When you arrive, leave your bags at our Bell Desk and start having fun! We'll text or email you when your room is ready so you know when and where to pick up your keys." (OK, I'll keep my eyes open for this, sounds good.)A few weeks before our December trip I received an email from Caesars mentioning that, "At times, premium rooms may go unsold. As a special offer, you can use the new Caesars Palace eStandby Upgrade® Program to potentially upgrade this reservation to a premium room." This sounded interesting so when we arrived (2:00 pm Wednesday) I went for this possible upgrade of only about $100. more per night for a 2 room suite. We were told the suite was not quite ready yet, give us your cell phone number and we'll notify you when it ready.  Well that notification never happened...and neither did the self-check in. It was now after 4:00 pm so we got in line (again) to re-check in and were told the suite was ready.  We went up the Forum Tower to "room #6419" only to find that yes it was a two room suite but with almost no view at all.  One of the two windows had been completely covered with a mirror type film so you could only see yourself, the other window looked out to a large concrete wall about 3' away and you would put your face on the windows far left had side you could see daylight!
Looks like we lost the view that we wanted after paying $100. more per night. I was so tired of walking around, trying to find the room\/suite that I really had lost all energy to go back downstairs and demand my original requested room with view of the strip.  This reminded me of a fishing trip once I booked on an old mine-sweeper ship in Canada where the cabin we had was right next to the engine room with no view of anything except yourself. What was worse (after unloading luggage in the suite with no view) no coffee maker unless you were willing to pay $13. to use their Keurig coffee set per use. It was the typical set up where you can't move anything (or use) the small refrigerator unless being charged for it. The lighting was bad even with every light turned on, but the A\/C did work.  The room\/suite itself was ok but nothing special (similar to the Embassy Suites concept) everything seemed rather dated.  The bathroom had a mirror TV in it and a whirlpool tub along with a walk in shower with three showerhead choices; the standard wall unit one would expect, a rainfall shower head from the ceiling and two small side spray massage showerhead nozzles. Luckily the floor we were on and the one above us was relatively quiet at night so we could sleep. We ended up paying $391. per night for their two room suite with one king bed, no view to mention, no refrigerator or working coffee maker unless you paid extra - gee - we could have done better...and we're not going back to this rip off hotel\/motel\/resort that's so large no one cares about the customers.

  If you enjoy second hand smoke, overpriced restaurants, getting lost and ripped off, Caesars Palace is for you.

At nearly $500\/night, I should not have to spend an hour going from front desk to concierge to security and back around trying to get someone to either issue me a new key or let me into my room. And even after my hour of trying to do this, I still don't have a workable room key.  Any one of the 8 employees I have spoken to could have helped me - but instead they choose to pass the buck to their coworkers rather than actually help a hotel guest.

We're waiting for our uber and the security Todd comes up to my girlfriend and I (we thought we were in trouble for blocking the walkway) and to our surprise he tells us not to go outside because it's raining and if we need help from creepy men to yell out his name and where to sit and where to walk to meet our uber. I've never had such a kind person offer us help before and can't express my appreciate him. Thank you Todd!!!

Ok so the suite was nice with the jetted tub, etc.  My main issues was with billing and customer service.  Since the billing issue so overshadows the stay I would be careful to stay here again.

Let me explain and you decide:

I left my debit for the deposit on the room...3 days later total was charged on my debit card! What makes this worse is that the room was already paid for so they charged for the room twice.  It took 4 days to get my money back from Caesars.  Learn from my mistake and use a credit card for your deposit card for your room.  Luckily I had the cash to cover it in my account or I would have been broke for 4 days waiting for my refund from here.

Stayed here recently for my birthday last month. We figured to go all out since we were celebrating a special occasion. We loved this hotel. We stayed in a room in the Laurel Tower. The room was beautiful, clean, and we loved the amenities. We payed $589 for two nights. The room was super quite and the bed was very comfortable.This place is where the action is. We were at other hotels at 1 am and they were slowing down. You walk into Ceasar's Palace at 1 am and it is happening! You would think it was 1 pm. We loved the hotel ambiance.  I don't know if we will be able to stay at another Vegas Hotel.

Das Caesers Palace ist sehr komfortabel. Der Fitnessraum ist eher durchschnittlich. Das Schwimmbecken ist genügend groß, mir fehlt jedoch ein Bad mit Strömung. Ansonsten kann der Service (eher wie höhere Mittelklasse) und die Größe der Suiten Punkten. Das Preis-Leistungs-Verhältnis finde ich ausgeglichen, den Preis gerechtfertigt. Das Caesars Palace ist zentral gelegen und Restaurant sind in unmittelbarer Nachbarschaft in Unmenge vorhanden.

It isn't what it used to be and it's starting to show its age compared to the newer more high end casinos next door (Bellagio, Aria, Vdara) However, there still is a lot to see and do a Caesars. The forum shops are still my favorite place to shop on the strip and the ceiling is one of the highlights. We don't gamble much, but every time I walk into Caesars I walk out with a little money unless she wants to go to the mall. The rooms are nice, but again there are better rooms in Vegas for much less... I guess there are perks to being an iconic Vegas hotel.
Was there on Monday 6\/29 it was the Worst run poker room I had ever played in. Total lack of knowledge and professionalism.  Will NEVER go back.

Just got out of Caesar's palace today. The motels around the strip are better than this place. We got a clogged bath tub in the room and the best part, I could not report this to the front desk as the phone was not working.
Love Caesars! My friends and I had an amazing time, definitely would come back. The only negative experience was how they nickeled and dimed us on the wifi after already paying the resort fee.

I like this hotel. It is old school and a bit upscale. They of course update things as required to stay up with the times. I like the Roman theme quite a bit, it still does not get old to me. The rooms are nice, especially if you get a suite. It was good sized, comfy and quiet when we wanted to sleep. The in house dining is quite good, as are the attached Forum Shops. The nightclub is great, other than the waiting to get in. You really can't go wrong here.

This had always been my favorite casino 
I always felt the had top notch service 
Haven't stayed here lately because they don't comp me free rooms anymore since I quite gambling and their room rates are generally high.  But every time I visit, I get the 5 star treatment from the workers as you would expect from a 5 star Vegas casino

Just came back from Vegas last week for my husbands birthday.  We stayed at the Augustus Tower.  The room was great!  Especially LOVED the oversized jaccuzzi tub with the TV in the bathroom.  I love Caesar's Palace! It's very convenient.  They have the infamous Forum Shops.  They have many great restaurants and centrally located.  I would love to stay here again.

Caesars, what's with the constant checking of our IDs? I understand we're not dressed in either cheap clubbing outfits from Old Navy or Forever 21, or that we weren't drunken morons just dropping money carelessly. I understand that we're just gamblers trying to play a card game without having every new dealer ask us for IDs. I understand that we were just dressed in a shirt and jeans. And I do understand that we're all well into our 30s and into his 40s and haven't been carded in a while.

Maybe it was our small stack that made you ask questions. But you see, at a $5 table, a stack of $200 should be acceptable. The stack of $5000 by the whale next to us is better suited for a higher limit table. But I know that's why you paid more attention to him and wanted him to win and showed us no care at all.

This same story followed me and my friends to Bally's; another Harrah's property. Just bad taste. The Harrah's properties have all been going downhill, and now crappy customer treatment seems to be their norm. I'll stay away and give my business to MGM properties instead. Stay classy Harrah's.
Internet didn't work. Walls are paper thin. guest services checked us out without asking despite a promise for late checkout. Pretty shitty hotel experience despite it's reputation

This is the real Caesars Palace.  Great, clean facilities. Fantastic shopping locations. Delicious food and of course the famous Bacchanal buffet.  This place is huge, so make sure you have enough time to explore!

If you stay here -get the Octavius Tower Deluxe room- amazing views facing the pools and huge bathroom!!! 

MOST IMPORTANTLY- HEAVENLY BED from The Laurel Collection. As soon as I lied down it was over, I didn't want to get up at all. I felt like I was on cloud 9. I'm not sure what padding they use but I want it!!! I LOVE THIS BED!!! I need this in my apartment asap. I would probably never go to work though....

The buffet is right by the elevator entrance. It is also a short walk to the BEST CLUB in vegas right now..OMNIA. 

5 stars overall but the bed deserves a 10 from a 1-10 scale!

Everything you need is here.

We stayed here on a stagette because the bride has seen "The Hangover" way too many times. Actually, I never asked her why this hotel... but she insisted that we stay here. I am glad she did because it seriously has everything you want... It's smoking hot in August (duh) so being somewhere with a decent nightclub, a bunch of restaurants, shopping, a beautiful pool, a convenience store... seriously, if need be, I wouldn't have had to venture outside.

We had booked a room in the Forum Tower. When we arrived, they upgraded us to the Palace Tower. Woot woot. Much bigger room with two washrooms. Perfect for three girls. If we were on a higher floor, we would have had a view of the pool. I think I saw the top of Snackus Maximus. I wish we had a fridge for our use since ours was filled to the brim with mini-bar regulars. But we had ice... after getting vodka and mixers from the store in the lobby, we were able to imbibe in the room. 

We spent a lot of time in the room since we spent a lot of time in the hotel. It was just so easy to pop upstairs to grab something or to drop off our shopping before coming back down to play the Big Buck Hunter slots. We wandered to Spago's in the Forum Shops before dancing the night away at Pure. 

Utter convenience.

Great ambiance.  Forum shops are great for designer labels.  Waitresses were quick to bring drinks at the slots.  The buffet sucks.  We went there for brunch and it was more like a continental breakfast.  Couldn't get my coffee or champagne refilled.  Had to go to the server station and do it myself.  Paris brunch was way better but the lines sucked at both.

This place is pretty cool. I only went there to grab a snack before catching dinner at the Bellagio but the atmosphere is a bit better here than other Vegas hotels. At least it wasn't over the top cheese like Paris, Excalibur, or others.

This review is specifically for the Augustus Tower accomodations:

Now a few years old, Augustus tower shows a few signs of wear but remains a top notch accomodation in Vegas. Geometric contrasts and dark browns accented by pastels make a modern continental style that is approachably hip (bright and airy but not overly feminine), with just a few Roman accents. High ceilings and a generous footprint, ceiling high leather headboards accent the plush pillows and bedding with honeycomb cotton blankets. Smaller flatscreen TV, but a huge mirror and comfortable seating area. The glass shower and spa tub are both oversize in the well--appointed bath (another small flatscreen and makeup mirror). Oh, and did we mention a fantastic view of the Bellagio fountains? [Make sure to request--no, DEMAND--the view room]

Caesars has a lot of interesting shows, nice shops, good deals every now and then and plenty restaurant to chose from. Highly recommend happy hour at sushi Roku and Trevi. Atlantis show on top of every hour is great to watch. Average casino and food court but they have few good restaurant like Palms, Spago etc.
Eat a piece of plastic from the food in the buffet. Manager did nothing. Will never come to eat again.

Is this the real Caesar's Palace, like the one that Caesar stayed in? Methinks not!

I was not impressed at all with the casino here. From the outside Caesar's Palace is absolutely beautiful, the arena, the tall pillars, statues and the clean ancient roman structure look. I think there is more hype about the resort than there is excitement. 

The girls dancing near the black jack table looked bored and lacked enthusiasm. There was definitely quite a bit going here at night with the line for club Pure and all of the casino traffic. Walking through the back area you can head to the gardens and the pool area which is huge and really nice. I will say it is better on the outside than on he inside.

I love VISITING this hotel during Vegas trips but actually staying there as a guest was a different story. I really wasn't all that impressed! I would say it was more a 2.5 but I'm rounding up to 3. 

They had a great deal last Thanksgiving & I scored a 3 night stay at around $80\/night. I always knew this property was HUGE but I didn't think it would bother me so much once I was actually a guest. 

The property of course is beautiful and I'm certain has gained so much popularity since the Hangover Movies (the gift shops even sells Hangover merchandise). We supposedly got a renovated room and it was pretty nice - spacious, clean, and beds were very comfy. The walk down the endless  hallways to the elevator was not fun especially after a tiring night. The crazy maze to get to the parking garage was insane too - like a good 15min walk. It's not that easy to find parking either lol. 

The resort fee we paid was suppose to include internet which was spotty at best. I gave up and just used data on my phone. Every time I passed by the front desk there was ALWAYS a line that I didn't bother waiting in line to try get the internet issue fixed. 

The topping on the cake was looking forward to eating at Bacchanal the whole trip and on our last night we tried to go and the ETA was 240min - no one should have to wait THAT long for a buffet! Hotel guests should get priority or something because that's plain ridiculous. 

I just feel like there are great deals for hotels all other the strip - do yourself a favor and pick a smaller property. Come as a visitor and go shopping, grab a drink, have dessert at Serendipity or see a show instead and it will be much more enjoyable.

Sure there's lots of stuff to do inside this enormous casino\/mall, but dear God, does that equate to a lot of inconvenient walking when all I wanted to do at the time was check in.  The self-park garage was clear on the other side of the property from the lobby and check-in took a long time.  But let's be positive for a second, the gentleman helping us check in was very helpful and was able to get my fiancé and I in a room down the hall from our friends (until they got another upgrade, more on that later).  I've also heard rumors that Caesar's is the easiest hotel to get lost in, and I'm a believer.

We stayed in a Roman tower room that was comfortable, but still visually reminded me of a Motel 6.  Our friends upgraded to a room in the Palace tower, complete with enormous tub and bidet.  I'll admit that room was much closer to the 4.5-star standard than ours was.  Wasn't that bad though since we were out most of the night anyway, but didn't feel like a good value.

If you're more interested in exploring and just need a bed to crash on when it's all over, then you're good - just bring comfortable shoes.

i stayed here for 3 nights. their concierge\/customer service is out of this world. they really know how to treat their guests. the pool area is sooo beautiful and amazing (look at photo posted). the European bathing area was quite an experience, though. haha (naked peoples!!) i loved sun bathing, drinking up mojitos, pina coladas, and martini's by the pool, and swimming for hours and hours. 

fabulous sculptures, cleo and caesar walking around the hotel, one of the hottest clubs (PURE), lounges, Forum Shops, Celine Dion show, bars, and DUHHHHH the Casino is awesome! lol. i loved my stay here. make it your stay.

3 stars for the outside appearance of Caesars. It's huge as hell! I like the Forum Shops here. I've never stayed here before: Way too pricey for my taste, but at least it's nice to look at for free! LOL

What was once the star of the strip is now overshadowed by its neighbors.  Still there is plenty to like about this place.  The restaurants have improved significantly over the past 2 years with the addition of the Bacchanal Buffet and Gordon Ramsey Pub.  However the casino is poorly laid out, the shopping is a mess, the forum shops are difficult to navigate and the rooms a disappointment for the money (nice rooms, too high a price).  Still this place has some great shows including Absinthe and is home to Serendipity III where people watching over desert is an art form!

There is a lot to like here but a lot to improve as well.

Stayed here for my bachelor party. The hotel was great, there were no issues at all. At check in I attempted the "secret sandwich," which scored us a room with two bathrooms and a great view of the pool. Customer service was great all throughout the hotel. We requested extra towels, and they were immediately brought to us. Gambling is okay here, but be advised table minimals are a little higher than other casinos. Still, a great place to stay and gamble. I would also definitely join Total Rewards while you are there.

Surprisingly enough, this was my first time I ever stayed at this hotel.  Why?! This place was awesome! Hence the fact this is an older hotel it's still up to date with on a lot of cool stuff! One of the biggest night club in Vegas (Pure) and Celine Dion was there! 

We stayed at the Augustus Tower which was not great, but not bad for the price *cough*cough*FREE!*cough*cough* My heart still belongs to Wynn\/Encore, but a change in scenery would be nice.

Im very disappointed with my experience at Cesar palace tonight. Tonight at 3:30 am coming out of Omnia I went to island bar right out of the club and the bar tender denied me water and said they only offer water bottle service. Basically I had to have $5 for WATER! What kind of place ONLY sells water? Pretty unethical! 
If management cares at all about this the employee that denied me water, was and older man on the heavy side light blue eyes.

We stayed for three nights recently and enjoyed our stay. We were in the cheapest room in the forum tower and thought it would be somewhat crappy. We was pleasantly surprised. The shower had a rain shower head and a standard. It was all marble and big enough for two. The bathroom mirror had a built in tv inside. There's a separate toilet area also. The bedroom area had a mirrored headboard and the bedding was actually quite nice. There was a sofa and a sofa chair in the room also. I've been to Vegas numerous times and this was the nicest standard room I've ever been in. It's not amazing but it's amazing for the price. I was extremely satisfied with the room.

The only negative thing I have to say about our stay is about the check in process. Check in was 4pm. We got to the front desk person at four o'clock on the dot. The front desk person started checking us in and somehow they didn't have a room available yet. If I wanted to pay to upgrade to a better room I could have that now otherwise it would be an hour or two before we'd get in a room. My girl and I were pissed. Planet Hollywood tried this BS on our last stay there and they're owned by the same company. We declined the upgrade and then he said maybe one of the rooms being cleaned would be ready in a half hour to an hour. Maybe. They'll call me. We went to a bar in the lobby to cool down and sure enough they called in a half hour to say the room was ready. What I don't understand is why if checkout is at 11am they don't have my room ready by 4pm. It's bad enough you can't check in 'til four but then they try to get you to upgrade to check in on the time they set. How long until check in is at 6, 7, or even 8? The biggest reason I stay at Harrahs properties is the whole "No Resort Fees" thing.
Great hotel.   It has a delicious buffet and the hotel is conveniently located across from Bally's and Bellagio.  It has great shops as well to escape the heat during the day.

We stayed here after we got an awesome deal on Vegas.com. The room was cleans and comfortable. Some amenities were outdated, but given we got a steal, we didn't care. They also only had one mirror in the room (surprising) and we had three women in one room, so getting ready was a bit of a challenge.

We don't give out 5 star reviews so easily, but this locale deserves it.

Check in took less then 4 minutes, the spacious hallways led us to our room in the newly renovated Augusta tower with exquisite views of the fountain and Bellagio.

Due to the high volume of visitors to Vegas, always look for hotels constantly revamping and remodeling!

The room was huge and this germaphobe really appreciated the detailed eye from our maid.  The walls were thick and soundproof, we just assumed we were the only guests on that floor (hotel was actually at capacity).

No coffee and no robes provided, was the only odd observation. Starbucks downstairs is the best option.

I haves stayed in Vegas many times and would return here in a heartbeat. Maybe Nobu next time? 

Mesa Grill and the Bacchanel buffet gives you little reason to leave the property.

Loved it!!

I can't say that I spent a lot of time inside my actual room, however Caesars Palace as a whole really delivers. There's plenty to do inside this hotel. For example, eating at their numerous restaurants, partying at Club Omnia, and of course GAMBLING! The bartenders here also aren't shy when It comes to making strong drinks. I believe our bartender called our drink a "strong Island" and it almost knocked me off my feet. But for almost $20 it had should've. My favorite part of this hotel is simply the art and decor of everything. The entire hotel looks so aesthetically pleasing that it takes a while to take it all in. I will definitely be back on my next Vegas trip.

We checked in and were upgraded to the Octavius tower. That and the Augustus tower are in the best location, close to the pool, buffet and exit to Las Vegas Blvd. You only have to walk across the casino to get to the forum shops.  

The casino was only mildly smokey, I am usually sensitive to it, but it was OK. I did not smell of smoke after being there. 

Pool was great, swim up black jack, great bar and food, lots of choices for swimming, lots of shade too! We were there in June.  

The Tower rooms have a VIP valet, that was wicked quick! Free too! 

Room was great, large bathroom, couch area, soft but comfy beds. 

Hubby enjoyed the SMOKE FREE poker room. 

Service was impeccable throughout our stay! 

The $25\/night "resort" fee was annoying,  but that got you free, pretty fast internet.

My stay was awful so why am I giving it 5 stars? Because Caesers employs an operations manager by the name of Martha. She was professional and attentive when I raised my issues and I understand how difficult that is to do at a place that gets as many visitors as Caesers does. Thanks Martha. 

Original review below:


The service has gone really down here. I travel all over and stay in hotels all the time. This is by far the worst hotel experience I've had. I waited in line for 45 minutes and the lady at the front desk said she's leaving for the night and just left me there. She didn't even bother to have someone else help me. More importantly when I was able to check in, they said they didn't have anymore double bed rooms available. I made it specifically clear when I RESERVED my room through Caesers, that I needed two beds. Instead I got a room with ONE bed that was a smoking room that smelled like an ashtray. I was then billed for stuff from the mini bar that I didn't take. When I called to dispute, they said they would investigate and if it's missing I'm on the hook. Wow. I've never been so mistreated at a hotel. I recommend you avoid this place, they don't seem to care about your business.

Me likey:)

Poker room and nice rooms to shower in (spent a total of 4 hours in 3 days in it but whatever)

I was here working a trade show at Caesar's. I told them when I checked in and they gave me a room in the same area as the convention. I also happened to slip how VIP I was that Paris gave me a complimentary  upgrade-just to give them a opportunity to level the playing field. They took good care of me giving me a room in the Palace tower. Beautiful new clean rooms, plasma tv, full mini bar, plasma tv(with movie rentals). Very nice

My not so VIP coworker was given a room in the Roman tower. It paled it comparision. If I had stayed in that tower I would not be so happy. I think it's where the ruckus starter are stuck together--kinda like a slum. JK!


The casino also has one of the best poker rooms around. No smoking allowed! Which in my book would make them six stars if I could give them a super special bonus star....

I lived at the poker room, I was the semidelusional chick ranting and raving with a lot of chips (if anybody was there June 29\/30th) I slept about 4 hours total over 3 days so I got weirder every night. But our table was the one laughing the most so I think it was all good.

Anways I would say this is on my 3 top places to stay in Vegas.

See ya guys there sometime:)

First timer here. Very overwhelming inside I must say. Better have a road map. Jk. Anyway it's a lot going on here at this place. From the time u pull in front to ever time u go downstairs. Was on the 11th floor in a deluxe room. It was cool,bathroom was very nice although the jacuzzi tub was prob the loudest I have ever experienced. Room service was fast but pricey but that's to be expected. Even the engineering dept was prompt as I asked if the heat could be turned on. Several places to eat but u must try the buffet!!!!! Good location, clubs inside, several bars,  a 24 hr somewhat diner, several places to shop and every famous chef must have a restaurant near. Yada yada. I would come back but it's a couple other hotels I would like to try also. Oh well. Out here

They were running a special on a Sunday night and we booked a room for $100. The man at the front counter upgraded us to a deluxe room and it was amazing! Two bathrooms, a whirlpool jet bathtub, amazing view, king bed- too good to leave the room. We were definitely spoiled- but the restaurant options, shopping areas, and games were all amazing. Definitely coming back!

3.75 stars.

Among the casinos on the Strip, Caesars is a sprawling behemoth. Filled with shops, absurd statues, and smoke, Caesars offers everything from working girls, dazzling beauties, and Cher to obese couples dressed in matching tee shirts covered with images of dollar bills. The sprawling space has surprisingly few tables, though, even on Friday nights. Very few options for grabbing a quick bite, but the conference rooms and services are excellent. The rooms are minimalist and spacious, with tubs and showers for couples in most rooms, king beds with goose down blankets and pillows, and velvet couches. Comfortable, but not luxurious.

My room was very nice and comfortable, and I expected to give Caesars a much higher rating, but....

They raised their room service prices but didn't check to make sure they updated all the menus in the rooms. I ordered an omelet for breakfast and what was listed as a BOTTLE of Dr. Pepper. The bottle was actually a 12 ounce can (menu price for the BOTTLE was $6, actual price for the can was $7). The omelet was $3 more than the menu price, and the room service charge was actually $10 when the menu said it was $6. When all was said and done I was overcharged by $10!

They did honor the menu prices, but it look a lot of work and no fewer than 3 phone calls to get them to do it.

I also had a problem with the internet. It wouldn't stay connected. I don't know if they needed to reboot the routers or just get new ones, but it was very frustrating.

Additionally, I don't know where Caesars ranks as far as the total number of hotel rooms, but the the place is absolutely huge with no fewer than 7 towers. Being big isn't inherently bad, but the layout is, especially for a property this large. They gave me a map when I checked in and even with the map I kept getting lost.

Oh yeah, be prepared for a very high resort fee.

Again, the room was very nice, so I won't say that I'm not going to stay there again, but I have stayed at better hotels for less, so it definitely won't be my first choice.

So i'm not a person to write bad reviews but my experience this past weekend is warranted for a review.

I've stayed here at Caesar's once before and had absolutely no issues and that's exactly why I chose to stay here again.

First off I usually book my rooms online and never call to book my reservations but this time I decided to. the first person I spoke with said the room I wanted  was sold out and then gave me prices for the different rooms available. I told her i'd talk it over with my boyfriend & I would call back. Maybe 5 minutes later I speak to a different representative & she stated the information the previous rep gave me was invalid, & to make matters worse the prices I was quoted were had over $100 difference. In short I got the room I wanted at the price I was originally quoted. 

Upon check-in after receiving our room keys we went upstairs and opened the door and there were people's things in the room, so we had to go all the way back downstairs to fix the issue, come to find the lady who checked us in gave us the wrong room number. Then back upstairs we went.

So like I said I've stayed here before & did not understand why OUR room had no door for the bathroom.. I mean I don't really need the privacy with my boyfriend but when it comes to using the restroom particularly #2 a door would have been nice.

THEN, there was a dried blood like stain on the sheets. I mean I haven't had this bad of an experience even in a cheaper hotel or motel.

AND no free Wi-Fi!!! are you kidding me, after a $28 resort fee per night you still can't offer that to your guests!?

I did ask for late check out for all the inconveniences & they still couldn't give me that!

Last thing that I didn't appreciate was that after we had spent $$ at places Caesar's owns the woman who checked us out gave us a coupon book we couldn't even use because we were leaving. Weren't they supposed to hand us that during check in?

However the only thing I enjoyed here was room service. The food was great!

Anyways it's not like I'm never gonna stay at a Caesar's entertainment property every again, but this experience sucked so bad!!

I can't believe how bad Caesars Palace has become. It took me an hour to check in. They told my wife that she couldn't park the xar in Valet. I was put on hold for 30 minutes by guest services. And then told by the asst guest services manager that this was the way it was because it was a busy weekend.  It is the middle of July and 110 out-a lot of big rollers in town really. Usually stay at Wynn and Bellagio.  Thought I would try Caesars again-bad idea.

A long-time Vegas lover. Go here every year. Didn't stay at Caesars, but went to spend an afternoon shopping and gambling. Ready to leave, we asked where the cashier's cage was. Though we were in a significant casino room with dealers and tables near the Forum Shops, there was not a single cashier there. Ok, so we had to walk down a long hall and to another casino. Finally we see it. And there are 50 people on line and ONE teller for non-reward card holders. And this is a SATURDAY NIGHT. After about 30 minutes of waiting, people start to get agitated. Management is summoned and shrugs their shoulders. And it isn't until a full-court rebellion (people literally shouting their complaints) ensues, that they finally turn over the SEVERAL reward windows for the common folk. That's after tons of people literally yelling and demanding decent customer service. Totally disrespectful. Never ever coming back to Caesars again.

I used to like Caesars... This time around was a big miss.  Hostile check-in with no budge on $40\/day resort fee for services I don't need, $10\/day to park (used to be free), room had clogged AC filter which we had to call and have replaced for AC to run properly, no robes in the room, coffee machine but Keurig cups are $13, fire alarm went off at 2am (???) on the first night.  Overall, the place is super crowded.  The casino is no exception - for many years all tables were $25 minimum, now everything is $10 with endless amateurs clogging things up.  Buffet didn't live up to the hype. For nearly Wynn-like prices, this place is a bust.

I love Caesars Palace. Just my opinion, but I think they have the best general common areas. The casino is huge and they have plenty of interesting and fun shops. 

It took my friends and I couple hours roamed around the Caesars. I think the only downside is that they are not connected to any other hotels and after walking so much, it will be nice to be able to just hop from the Caesars to another hotel. 

P.S: Wear your most comfortable shoes. Your feet will thank you.

Caesar's is a gorgeous hotel and casino. The lobby is clean, spacious and beautiful. The Palace Tower rooms are very nice, especially the suite. The room itself isn't huge, but the double his and her bathroom with the walk through clear glass connecting shower, is. 

From the 26th floor, the view of the pools is STUNNING! It's better than the original Roman baths. Caesars has about 6 pools, complete with fountains, marble, decorative floors and my fave, a swim up gaming table. The architecture and design, from the layout of the chairs to the graceful curve of the staircase, make the view looking down truly stunning. 

The pools are nice, and if you're a size 24 or a size 2, it doesn't matter.

The $19.95 lunch buffet is wonderful! Crab legs, omelets, steak, huge array of vegetarian salads and big fat dessert table make for a delicious and overwhelming feast. 

I highly recommend!

The Laurel Collection. I got upgraded last year when they reopened these new rooms. I felt like royalty. The room suites my taste in decor and elegance it was a perfect reflection of my style. The property is huge, I can easily stay here and not step foot outside, it was that grand. The casino has seen its days from deteriorating pillars to name tags seen at the craps table, I'm sure there's a story to them every night. The buffet is amazing and always great service. The pool is well maintained and looks gorgeous for a poolside wedding reception. I love this venue.

I love Caesars! The room was amazing. Very clean, they also have nice pools.

Downstairs with the shopping stores and everything is very nice. Everything is expensive though but I love it. Great place to shop

We came, we gambled, we won, they gave us cool rewards and comps on my players card, so we returned. Thats the cliffs note version, but let
me tell you why this is my new favorite 5 star hotel
casino in Las Vegas. I asked my rewards agent to book me a room
on a friday night, she said it was going to be $99\/nt on a friday night-amazing right? When I got there and checked in, I debated asking for a room upgrade, but glad i didnt. When I got
to my room,
it was a full on suite, 2000sq ft with an amazing view. 

I love this place and will definitely return!

This place is awesome.

No tiger in my bathroom this trip, but fun fun fun.

I stayed here for 3 nights and had a blast.  The service is amazing and the location could not be better.  My room in the Augustus tower was very nice with everything you could want.  I had to wait for the buffet however it was just amazing.  The mushroom truffle soup was to die for.

If you are going to Vegas, try to stay here, you will be very happy.

Although Ceasar's struggles with many of the typical problems I have with big casinos on the strip(old people, screaming children, temperature control issues), it was overall better than I had initially expected.  Our room had just been remodeled, and was pretty nice.  Not dingy at all.  Also, we had a TV in the bathroom mirror which was really convenient while we were there on November 3rd, trying to keep up with the presidential election as much as possible while we were partying in Vegas.  

A couple of issues, however.  Apparently, the entire Forum Tower was experiencing some sort of engineering difficulty, and there was a loud noise coming from our door lock throughout the entire stay.  The actual noise it was making is hard to explain; but it was loud enough to wake me up every 15 minutes during the night when it occured.  However, they did comp us the bottle of 2003 Clos du Val Cabernet Sauvignon that was in the mini bar after I called and complained about the mechanical noise.

Another issue:  there is a lack of hotel security in the late hours of the night\/early hours of the morning.  I was walking back to my room alone after leaving my boyfriend to play at one of the blackjack tables for a bit longer, and some sleaze followed me back to the elevators, cornered me and propositioned me like a prostitute, telling me to "name my price".  As I frantically looked around for someone, ANYONE, to help me, there was no hotel employees around to assist me, and thank god he didn't follow me into the elevator after I scurried away.  I mean, I acknowledge that sometimes I dress provocatively, but not this time. This guy was just completely out of line, and there was no security guard in the elevator area making sure outsiders couldn't wander up into the hotel or assault the guests.

But, other than that, Caesar's wasn't as bad as I thought it would be.  The Forum Shops cant be beat; having Vegas's best shopping right at your fingertips was awesome(and bad at the same time).  And, the Elton John show was outstanding!  Definitely check The Red Piano show out.

Caesars Palace may look impressive on the outside, but inside customer service is nil. Check-in is by machine, no personal greeting. Our room, while spacious is literally miles away from the restaurants and casino. Forget complimentary coffee. Although there is a mini Kerig in the room you have to pay for the pods. There is a charge for wifi too.  I am surprised the ice is free. Next time I will stay in a hotel the cares for its guests.

I only stayed here over night but my stay was absolutely amazing. I loved Caesars hotel room. It was very updated, clean and the bed is EXTREMELY soft-- the entire room put into one word can be described as elegant. I recommend checking out the buffet here and bringing a completely empty stomach! The casino is very clean and I always have a great time here. It gets a little crowded in the casino area since it's right next to their new club called Omnia (which is a great club BTW).

Came here to attend Ms. Celine Dion's concert. I loved the way it was organized but the concert was too short and it took so long to get to the auditorium. Security told us no pictures with flash and no filming, but no one followed the rules. I like consistency, if you have all these crazy rules discipline the obvious suspects.

Stayed here for 4 days and 3 nights and loved it! We were supposed to stay in the Roman Tower but they upgraded us to the Palace Tower for free. The room was beautiful, clean and spacious. This hotel is on the strip and relatively close to everything else. I would definitely stay here again!

Beautiful.
 Stayed here on an overnite trip and found it hard to leave! The service from check in to check out, and everything inbetween was flawless. 
 The propety itself is enormous and easily to get lost. 
 There's great places to eat here, though we didn't. Had to go back to Piero's. 
But they have a bar called the Galleria or something. The mixed drinks seemed a bit lite on the vodka, but service from Frank the bartendar was good. He was attentive n friendly. 
 I do recommend this hotel for anyone looking for an amazing visit.

This review is for the Augustus Tower room at Caesars, plus the property in general.

We stayed at Caesars in April of 2015 and got the Augustus Tower room. The first annoying thing was that we were promised a "separate check in area" for Augustus or Octavius Tower rooms, just to find out that those check in areas have been closed since January 2015. So basically, you're paying for a premium check in experience but you have to stand in line with everyone else at the basic hotel check in. Because of this, there isn't any reason to use the side Valet entrance because there's no bell desk and no special check in. Plus if you exit on this side entrance there's a skeevy half block walk to the Strip that smelled of sewage.

Check in was annoying. Long lines (on an off-season Wednesday morning no less), and they charge you $20 to "text me when the room is ready", or a $40 "early check in fee". It felt really tacky. We neglected the "Bellagio Fountain View" upgrade for another $40 a night so our view was of the north side of the Strip.

Room itself was great. Nice big bathroom with a soaking tub, separate shower, and dual sinks, sitting room with a desk and table and a couch. Flatscreen TV was an unimpressive 30" model, barely visible from the bed itself. No storage space in the fridge and anything you touch or move in the minibar, you pay for. High speed internet was decent, but also limited in yet another nickel-and-dime tacky way because your $32 resort fee only covers 2 devices per day. So if you have a couple of phones, a laptop, and a tablet, you're out of luck getting them all on the wifi.

Pool was okay, but until 1PM, half the pool area is covered in shadow. Paid $38 for two 16oz from-a-machine slushy alcoholic drinks at the bar, which seemed about $10 too much. Waiter service was very slow, only was visited once during a 3 hour stay. Mattress lounge chairs by the pool rent for $200 a day, $300 on weekends. Cabanas are much more expensive.

Compared to the places like the Venetian, Cosmopolitan, and Aira, the crowd was definitely older, and of a lower.. "quality" for lack of a better word. This is not a young and hip crowd and there was a surprisingly large amount of families here with very young kids and babies.

The casino was smaller than I expected, smoky, and a huge step down from the likes of the Venetian, Cosmopolitan, and Aria. The deep smoke smell seemed to be embedded in all the carpets and furniture, reminding me of the old casinos in downtown Vegas. All of the slot machines seemed to be models that were 2 years old or more, with an overall small selection compared to the tons of variety you find elsewhere in newer casinos. Very few of the large modern video machines (ie Willy Wonka, Rolling Stones, etc). Mostly slot machines were the J\/Q\/K\/A variations of the GameKing video slot machines. Plus the place was packed - there were times in the evening where you couldn't find a table to play at. I found myself wandering endlessly around the casino looking for anything interesting to play. In the end, I did most of my gambling elsewhere.

I would stay here again if I could get the upgraded Augustus or Octavius tower rooms for less than $140 a night. Otherwise, the overall Caesar's experience just isn't worth paying more than that.

Caesar is tired and so is his palace.  Service is weak, problems don't get dealt with. Everything is overpriced beyond acceptability, I know it's a "resort" in a touristy town, but sorry, $14 for a pint of beer is stupid.  I guess I was stupid not to ask.  Not a fan, bordering on 1 star.

Get to the Chase:

Pros:
1) As grand as you expect it to be...or saw in The Hangover :p
2) Swanky Greco-style! Amazing artwork, decor, and definitely Caesar salad ballerness
3) I'd recommend it most certainly, but prepare to pay some mooola $$ cuz you won't be saying "It aint no thang"

Cons:
1) Could put more emphasis on giving the vibe of each guest being royalty...but I guess that's just logisitically impossible or too costly...but I'd say I should feel like a friggn Caesar in my PALACE! (gorgeous people feeding me grapes, transportation by human-drawn chariots, my own personalized robes with gold embroidery, a platter of roasted boar and fresh fruits, wine by the jugs!) NOW THAT's Caesar-ness

I hate to do this because I work the in the industry but the way this hotel is managed is absolutely appalling. 

We checked in this morning to the "upgraded room" that was $200 on a Monday night. I have no problem paying for quality but it is the opposite of what we got. When we walked into our first room it was overwhelming stinky with weed smell. Which is not problem if it's a little but it was like walking into a cloud. Then we requested rooms customer service was absolutely ridiculous and rude and I had to beg to be switched. When we finally get switched this room smells too! Invest in some febreeze Caesar! And multiple of the electronics didn't work. Then they sent someone to fix it who made us leave our room for two hours! I'm not a picky person but seriously! Then no upgrades or anything of any kind. I am very disappointed and it is unfortunate because I am in Vegas very often. I will not be returning.

We didn't stay in the hotel at Caesar's, but he did eat at the buffet downstairs. Out of the 5 buffets we had on the trip, this was the best! Our server was fabulous, and the food selection was great! My only complaint is that they did not offer cotton candy for dessert like the other buffets! :)
I still love this joint! But hey, it's Caesars Place! It was built in 1966 and still holds it's own. Just go there and enjoy everything.
Caesars Buffet is just terrible. Not only terrible but expensive for lousy food. The food is terrible. If you want to feel ripped off with the bad food eat there.

Okay I read the other reviews. .and what happened to me in Vegas will not remain only in Vegas. Im here to report. 

Yes. ..the palace tower room we had was gorgeous perfect sleep comfy mattress you never want to leave 4 pillows plus neck rolls. .bidet 2 bathrooms  great tv big hot tub right there.next to the sink.extra big towels.new looking.But that's why I gave it t hat third star. Maybe some rooms are older and we got lucky. But as good as it was, I hate bad service,and although some employees were perfect some of the ones I encountered were just rude. 

No offer to help us find the room or assist with bags...a map was given. It's a huge property. I had to stop twice to rest. Shop employees hawking, trying to drag me inside like at a flea market.

 No inroom coffee pot.you have to pay almost thirteen dollars for a coffee set up.which consists of mostly various fake sugars.not enough fake cream and real sugar for one good cup. No cookie no breakfast discount or sweet roll.. didn't like the apple scented shampoo..sorry.

We got there about 8pm. No option to check out later even paying extra.11 a.m.is too early in that town. 

I could go on,but I will review the restaurants separately. Basically overpriced mixed service average food. 

Hugo the valet,adam the steakhouse waiter and his assistants, Debra the phone operator,Summer the cage cashier Almira the casino club cashier, all deserve praise. But I'm always nice,polite,smiling,  and I encountered way too many snippy dismissive employees for such a reputable establishment. 

The only way I would return would be getting a great price to cover all the lack of reasonably priced amenities.  Hopefully the bill will be correct.they added a two hundred dollar amenity charge even though we didn't touch the minibar or purchase inroom food or movies.

Try to plan ahead carefully. Best of luck to you.

Great place on the strip to stay Their rooms are hit or miss!! I was in an outdated version that had a bathtub right next to the bed. Tacky!  Shops at the hotel are amazing and they have a lot of great restaurants to choose from.

Overall I'd say Caesar's is a nice resort and casino. The staff is friendly and the casino is clean and not smoky. The shopping is high end if that's what you're looking for and plenty of it.
The only negative is the room we were given. We we're in Roman Tower which is the oldest and you can tell. Even in a suite room we had carpet that was stained and about 20 years old. The furniture was a mix of the last 3 decades and the mattress was worn out and springy. It definitely needs some updating for being a top tier Vegas resort. We had two staff members who said they had never been in our room before. I think it's time management visits the 6th floor at least.

Once again, I'm commenting on the hotel grounds......haven't stayed here yet unfortunately, although my cousin swears they are the most comfortable beds ON THIS EARTH.  She loves staying here.  I just have never had the pleasure.  What I love about this hotel is that it is older elegance, and yet, it still draws throngs of crowds, young and old, refined and hip.  This place is still happening, and it's still beautiful, it continues to grow by leaps and bounds (I always see new things here everytime we come to Vegas) and it simply never disappoints.  The Forum Shops alone keep this place going, but this hotel continually boasts great entertainment, great dining, great hotel amenities (from what I hear), and whatever else tickles your fancy.  

What I love is that they were the first hotel to have a buffet....... their "Sunday Brunch."  I cannot tell you how special it was, and how much my family and I would create an entire trip around making sure we got to have Caesar's Palace Sunday Brunch.  Now?  Buffets are everywhere at almost every hotel, and not just on Sundays, and as for the famous Caesar's brunch, they have now downplayed and minimized the once great and amazing brunch.  That part makes me a little sad, but the memory of what it represented to us still lingers on in my mind and makes me smile.  It also dates me a little.  : )     Some of you know, though, what that brunch was all about !!

My aunt was a high roller here and loved this hotel.............perhaps, more than her children.   No, just kidding (I think).     :)

I'd really give it 1.5 stars but will settle for 2.

It's simple - overpriced rooms, food, drinks - ridiculous $28\/day resort fee - crummy wifi (for the $28 fee no less) - full resort wifi is another like $25\/day - the Roman Tower rooms are like the Motel 6 down the street - front desk service slow, slow, slow - the service for room issues was dismal.

Go elsewhere.

What can I say great hotel to stay.  Stayed here a few times over the past few years...never been disappointed  once...well except maybe one time the jets didn't work in my jacuzzi.  Otherwise beautifully decorated room.  Huge bathroom and yay for the lcd in the bathroom.  Conveniently located on the strip...great food and shopping.  O yea didn't hurt that I won money from the pai gow table either.   Remember stay in the Augustus Tower rooms and you won't be disappointed.

Great value if basic room in Forum Tower.  No view because original tower before Omnia night club and other additions.  Clean room. Convenience key.  No lame security watching elevator bank.  Starbucks, restaurants and Sports Book along with Colosseum theater for big acts 20 Yards from elevator.  Saves a lot of time since central location with tons of amenities.

The hotel room had plenty of room and looked nice on the surface but be prepared to be nicked and dimed.  They provide a Kurig but you have to pay $13 if you actually want coffee because they charge you for the Kcups.  They also provide a refrigerator in your room (advertised) but you can't actually use it because its full of drinks they want to sell you like a $7 gatorade.  There is ZERO room for your own food.  If you go to breakfast at their only breakfast place downstairs be prepared to pay $30 for a diner meal.  The real bummer is that the hotel is nice it just leaves a bad taste in your mouth because our hotel amenities bill ended up more than our nights stay and we didn't even do anything luxurious.  Lastly, be prepared to not check in until upwards of 6pm. They tell you in fine print that your room will be ready between 3pm - 6pm but we had to go find it because it was no where clear.  My suggestion Caesars would be pay attention to customer service and don't just lure guest in, learn how to treat them well and get rid of all the ludicrous nickel and dime services.  Guests without morning coffee can be quite grumpy!

First time I stayed there.... so I can't compare it to what it "used to be," nor can I say that it's taken a "nose dive" or anything.  Based on my first and only experience staying there, I was impressed.  We stayed in the Palace Tower, and our room was very good sized.  Nice jetted tub in the bathroom, very comfortable bed, plenty of room to spread out.  Cool design theme too.  Just be careful that you do not even TOUCH the snack\/convenience items on top of the fridge.  We accidentally knocked one down and had to immediately call the front desk so that we didn't get charged.
But the room itself was very nice, and the price was reasonable.

Casino - well...it's a Vegas lobby casino.  We're not clubbers so we didn't check out any nightclubs (despite the fact that Justin Bieber happened to be in the house that night....lol).  Many restaurant choices, nice pool as well (though the drinks via the waitress cost a small fortune - one mixed drink and a water came out to $20).  Lines for check-in were a mile long, check out wasn't so bad.  Biggest word to wise is to be careful of all the little fine-print charges...the mandatory activity fee for internet and the fitness center, all of the beverages they tempt you with in the room fridge (which you can't use for your own stuff), etc...

You probably get this a lot, this isn't the real Caesar's Palace is it? Did, umm... did Caesar live here? I didn't think so." It's ok that the real Caesar didn't live here, at least the place is pager friendly! 

I've always had a pleasant experience staying at Caesar's; although, I can't say the same about losing money while gambling here. You can't miss this massive property right off the Flamingo exit of the I-15.

Somehow, I always end up in the Palace Tower room. That's the room with the exhibitionist shower in between the two bathrooms. You'd think having two bathrooms is convenient until one person is taking a shower but has to lock both doors since the shower doors are glass. If you don't care, shower away and display what yo mama gave you. The dual showerheads make it fun to shower with a friend while doing the earth a favor by conserving water.

The furniture is modern and the rooms are upkept nicely. The beds are comfy I have no complaints. My last trip was with three guys and of course they forgot to pack some toiletries. They had someone bring up toothbrushes, shaving cream and razors, extra shampoo and conditioner, and soap. They even brought up extra robes and slippers.

We pulled an all nighter and I finally got to bed around 10am. We were all feeling lazy later on and they brought back dinner from the food court. Their food court actually has good food unlike food courts from other hotels.

Some may say overrated or not worth the price, but everyone should try the Bacchanal Buffet at least once!

Spent another weekend at Caesars, decided to give it another try after our last trip didn't end well. Caesars is a fantastic hotel and casino but they lack a proper communication system and customer service skills. 

Upon arrival we ordered room service to be delivered during normal hours and we were told it would take additional time to be delivered since we ordered during peak hours, we acknowledged but problem is our meals never arrived at all. Front desk apologizes but we were still billed!

We had ordered additional towels and soap for our room, none provided.

We had requested a wake up call, never called.

We were told to make reservations to get seats at a restaurant, when we arrived we waited over an hour because they had overbooked and could not accommodate us. 

Lastly, after scrambling to check out in time and not miss our flight, one of the bell service personnel misplaces our bag. He told us he would look into it immediately but at the time we didn't want to miss our flights we had to leave.
